item.title: Beth add a quote by Orson Scott Card
item.description: "None of us could be happy for long, doing nothing." -- Orson Scott Card

item.title: Beth add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Write about what really interests you, whether it is real things or imaginary things, and nothing else." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Beth add a quote by James Thurber
item.description: "Humor is emotional chaos remembered in tranquility." -- James Thurber

item.title: Beth add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "I never know what I think about something until I read what I've written on it." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Beth add a quote by Charles Proteus Steinmetz
item.description: "There are no foolish questions and no man becomes a fool until he has stopped asking questions." -- Charles Proteus Steinmetz

item.title: Beth add a quote by Henry David Thoreau
item.description: "I put a piece of paper under my pillow, and when I could not sleep I wrote in the dark." -- Henry David Thoreau

item.title: Beth add a quote by George Bernard Shaw
item.description: "When a man wants to murder a tiger he calls it sport; when a tiger wants to murder him he calls it ferocity." -- George Bernard Shaw

item.title: Beth add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "When people talk, listen completely. Most people never listen." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Beth add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "The intuitive mind is a sacred gift and the rational mind is a faithful servant. We have created a society that honors the servant and has forgotten the gift." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Beth add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "It takes your enemy and your friend, working together, to hurt you to the heart: the one to slander you and the other to get the news to you." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Beth add a quote by Theodore Roosevelt
item.description: "To announce that there must be no criticism of the President, or that we are to stand by the President, right or wrong, is not only unpatriotic and servile, but is morally treasonable to the American public." -- Theodore Roosevelt

item.title: Beth add a quote by Thomas Henry Huxley
item.description: "The chess-board is the world; the pieces are the phenomena of the universe; the rules of the game are what we call the laws of Nature. The player on the other side is hidden from us. We know that his play is always fair, and patient. But also we know, to our cost, that he never overlooks a mistake, or makes the smallest allowance for ignorance." -- Thomas Henry Huxley

item.title: Beth add a quote by Napoleon
item.description: "What is history but a fable agreed upon?" -- Napoleon

item.title: Beth add a quote by Roy H. Williams
item.description: "Our actions are all that separate our daydreams from our goals." -- Roy H. Williams

item.title: Beth add a quote by Roy H. Williams
item.description: "Small thoughts fit easily into a closed mind, but big thoughts require an open one." -- Roy H. Williams

item.title: Beth add a quote by George Augustus Moore
item.description: "A man travels the world over in search of what he needs and returns home to find it." -- George Augustus Moore

item.title: Beth add a quote by Henry Van Dyke
item.description: "It is better to burn the candle at both ends, and in the middle, too, than to put it away in the closet and let the mice eat it." -- Henry Van Dyke

item.title: Beth add a quote by Samuel Johnson
item.description: "Few things are impossible to diligence and skill. Great works are performed not by strength, but by perseverance." -- Samuel Johnson

item.title: Beth add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "Man is least himself when he talks in his own person. Give him a mask, and he will tell you the truth." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Beth add a quote by Samuel Johnson
item.description: "Read over your compositions, and wherever you meet with a passage which you think is particularly fine, strike it out." -- Samuel Johnson

item.title: Beth add a quote by Plato
item.description: "I have hardly ever known a mathematician who was capable of reasoning." -- Plato

item.title: Beth add a quote by Bill Cosby
item.description: "I don't know the key to success, but the key to failure is trying to please everyone." -- Bill Cosby

item.title: Beth add a quote by John Boyle O'Reilly
Beth add a quote by Abraham Lincoln
item.description: "You cannot escape the responsibility of tomorrow by evading it today." -- Abraham Lincoln

item.title: Beth add a quote by Terry Pratchett
item.description: "It is said that your life flashes before your eyes just before you die. That is true, it's called Life." -- Terry Pratchett

item.title: Beth add a quote by Martin Sheen
item.description: "I love my country enough to risk its wrath by drawing attention to the negative things we don't always want to see. And that can be risky and you have to pay for that. (Ramon Estevez) on Inside the Actor's Studio" -- Martin Sheen

item.title: Beth add a quote by Eleanor Roosevelt
item.description: "It is not fair to ask of others what you are not willing to do yourself." -- Eleanor Roosevelt

item.title: Beth add a quote by J.R.R. Tolkien
item.description: "It does not do to leave a live dragon out of your calculations, if you live near him." -- J.R.R. Tolkien

item.title: Beth add a quote by Anne Lamott
item.description: "Becoming a writer is about becoming conscious. When you're conscious and writing from a place of insight and simplicity and real caring about the truth, you have the ability to throw the lights on for your reader. He or she will recognize his or her life and truth in what you say, in the pictures you have painted, and this decreases the terrible sense of isolation that we have all had too much of." -- Anne Lamott

item.title: Beth add a quote by Terry Pratchett
item.description: "The trouble with having an open mind, of course, is that people will insist on coming along and trying to put things in it." -- Terry Pratchett
